title-group.article-title: Beneficial effect of astaxanthin on 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin-induced liver injury in rats

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Faculty of Science, Erzurum Technical University, Turkey
2Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Atatürk University, Turkey
3Department of Environmental Studies, Institute of Graduate Studies and Research, Alexandria University, Egypt

author-notes.corresp: Fatime Geyikoglu, Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Atatürk University, 25240 Erzurum, Turkey. Email: geyikogluff@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Exposure to 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) represents a potential health risk and hepatotoxicity. Astaxanthin (ASTA) exhibits antioxidant properties and can influence hepatotoxicity. Therefore, the present study was carried out for using ASTA against hepatotoxicity induced by TCDD in the liver of rats. Animals were treated intraperitoneally daily with TCDD (8 µg/kg body weight (b.w.)), ASTA (12.5 mg/kg b.w. and 25 mg/kg b.w.) and TCDD plus ASTA (12.5 and 25 mg/kg b.w.) for 21 days. TCDD significantly decreased the activities of antioxidant enzymes and resulted in serious pathological findings. Moreover, the rate of micronucleus (MN) in hepatocytes increased after treating with TCDD. The activities of enzymes, frequencies of MNs and liver histology in lower dosage group of ASTA remained unchanged compared with the control group. In rats treated with ASTA, at higher dosage alone, the MNs remained unchanged and the activities of antioxidant enzymes significantly increased. The presence of ASTA (except for lower dose) with TCDD alleviated its pathological effects in hepatic tissue. ASTA also prevented the suppression of antioxidant enzymes in the livers of animals exposed to TCDD and displayed a strong protective effect against MNs. Thus, the present findings might provide new insight into the development of therapeutic and preventive approaches of TCDD toxicity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Dioxin-like polyhalogenated aromatic hydrocarbons represent a major class of environmentally and economically relevant toxicants. 2,3,7,8-Tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) is a highly toxic persistent organic pollutant among these hydrocarbons (Chopra et al., 2010). Dioxins accumulate along the food chain particularly in liver and adipose tissue (Scrogi, 2008). In mammals, dioxin exposure leads to a broad spectrum of adverse affects, including hepatotoxicity of varying severity (Boutros et al., 2008). Exposures to dioxin and related compounds have been linked to increased prevalence of fatty liver in human beings (Lee et al., 2010). The marked change induced by TCDD is degeneration of the hepatocytes (Czepiel et al., 2010; Turkez et al., 2011a). Also, TCDD is a potent promoter of liver cancer (Huff et al., 1994).

Oxidative stress is involved in the onset of several disorders after TCDD exposure. Antioxidants play an important role in inhibiting and scavenging free radicals, thus providing protection to humans against infectious and degenerative diseases (Nader et al., 2010; Yildirim et al., 2011). Thus, there is an increasing interest in finding the appropriate agents with antioxidative protection for hepatocytes (Ciftci et al., 2011; Turkez et al., 2011b, 2011c, 2012; Yin et al., 2011). On the other hand, in vivo and in vitro studies of human and animal cells have provided inconsistent findings of genetic toxicity of TCDD. However, there are equivocal findings of chromosomal aberrations in humans exposed in vivo to TCDD (IARC, 1997) and increases the production of 8-oxo-2-deoxyguanosine in the liver of mice (Hung et al., 2006). Today, it is reported that dioxin-like chemicals alter the expression of numerous genes in liver, but it remains unknown, which lies in pathways leading to major toxicities such as hepatotoxicity, wasting and lethality (Forgacs et al., 2010).

Carotenoids are a class of natural fat-soluble pigments found principally in plants. They have potential antioxidant biological properties due to their chemical structure and interaction with biological membranes. The most abundant carotenoids in the diet are β-carotene, lycopene, lutein, β-cryptoxanthin, zeaxanthin and astaxanthin (ASTA). Numerous epidemiologic studies have supported the hypothesis that antioxidants could be used as an inexpensive means of prevention and possibly treatment of several diseases (Riccioni, 2009). The red carotenoid ASTA possesses higher antioxidant activity than other carotenoids and has great commercial potential for use in the aquaculture, pharmaceutical and food industries (Ukibe et al., 2009). ASTA, a major component of carotenoids, possesses attractive remedial features (Nagendraprabhu and Sudhandiran, 2009). ASTA modulates immune response, inhibits cancer cell growth, reduces bacterial load and gastric inflammation and protects against ultraviolet A-induced oxidative stress in in vitro and rodent models (Park et al., 2010). The hepatoprotective effects of ASTA have been studied, and these researchers indicate that ASTA via increasing the activity of antioxidant enzymes and/or level of glutathione (GSH) decrease oxidative stress (Curek et al., 2010; Riccioni, 2009). Further investigations to determine the mechanisms underlying this protective effect in chemical-induced toxicity are required (Kawada et al., 2009). However, no attention was paid to the effects of ASTA in the hepatoprotection against TCDD; also the information regarding the effects of ASTA on micronucleus (MN) and antioxidant enzymes such as catalase (CAT) in hepatocytes remains unknown. In our present study, we examined the effects of ASTA on histological structure in TCDD-induced liver injury. We also evaluated the role of ASTA on enzymatic antioxidant activities and MN after TCDD treatment.

sec.title: Experimental design and animals
sec.p: Experiments were performed on male Sprague-Dawley rats, 8 weeks old, weighing 165–190 g. The animals were kept on a 12-h light–dark cycle and allowed free access to food and water. All experiments were performed in accordance with the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (National Research Council, 1996). A total of 48 rats were randomly divided into six equal groups: group 1 was used as the control (given only dimethyl sulfoxide), group 2 received 8 µg/kg body weight (b.w.) TCDD daily (CAS No. 1746-01-6, Sigma-Aldrich, St Louis, Missouri, USA) intraperitoneally for 21 days; groups 3 and 4 received 12.5 and 25 mg/kg b.w. ASTA daily (CAS No. 472-61-7, Sigma-Aldrich) intraperitoneally for 21 days; groups 5 and 6 were treated simultaneously with TCDD and ASTA daily for 21 days. The doses were selected according to the literature data (Czepiel et al., 2010; Tripathi and Jena, 2010). At the end of the treatment period, the animals were anesthetized with ether and liver samples were obtained. Liver tissues were separated in three portions. The first part was used for the determination of activities of antioxidant enzyme and level of GSH, the second part was used for MN analysis and the third part was used for histological examinations.

sec.title: Biochemical studies
sec.p: The tissue preparation was performed according to the procedure previously described by Skrzydlewska and Farbiszewski (1997). The liver samples were placed in iced NaCl (0.15 M), perfused with the same solution in order to remove the blood cells, then blotted on filter paper, weighed and homogenized in 9 volumes of ice-cold 0.25 M sucrose and 0.15 M NaCl, with the addition of 6 ml of 250 mM butylated hydroxytoluene in ethanol to prevent the formation of peroxides during the assay. The homogenization procedure was performed under standardized conditions. Homogenates (10%) were centrifuged at 10,000 r/min for 15 min at 4°C and the supernatant was kept on ice till assayed. The protein content in the liver was measured by the method of Lowry et al. (1951). Activity of superoxide dismutase (SOD) in supernatant was measured according to the method of Misra and Fridovich (1972). Activities of CAT in liver tissues were measured according to the method of Aebi (1984). Activity of glutathione peroxidase (GSH-Px) in liver was determined according to the method of Lawrence and Burk (1976). The measurement of reduced GSH in liver tissue was performed as described by Akerboom and Sies (1981).

sec.title: Liver MN assay
sec.p: Liver MN assay was done using the method of Suzuki et al. (2009). Isolated hepatocytes from rats were prepared by the collagenase perfusion technique (Wang et al., 2002). To remove blood, liver was perfused through the hepatic portal vein with calcium-free Hank’s balanced salt solution at a flow rate of 2.5 ml/min for about 10 min. As soon as the liver becomes grayish brown in color, a second buffer solution containing collagenase (Hank’s balanced salt supplemented with 4 mM calcium chloride and 0.5 mg collagenase/ml) was perfused at the same rate until the liver appeared to have broken up. Then the liver is minced into 3–4 mm pieces with a sterile scalpel. Following mechanical dissociation, the cells were filtered through gauze and centrifuged at 1350 r/min for 5 min. The hepatocyte pellets were suspended in 10% neutral-buffered formalin and stored under refrigeration. Immediately prior to evaluation, 10–20 μl of hepatocyte suspension was mixed with an equal volume of acridine orange (AO) and 4′,6-diamidino-2-phenylindole dihydrochloride (DAPI) stain solution (AO: 0.5 mg/ml; DAPI: 10 μg/ml) for fluorescent staining. Approximately 10–20 μl of the mixture was dropped onto a glass slide and covered with a cover glass. Samples of well-isolated hepatocytes were evaluated using a fluorescence microscope by counting the number of micronucleated hepatocytes (MNHEPs) in 2000 hepatocytes of each animal. MNHEPs were defined as hepatocytes with round or distinct MNs that stained like the nucleus, with a diameter of one fourth or less than that of the nucleus, and confirmed by focusing up and down, taking into account the hepatocyte thickness.

sec.title: Histological studies
sec.p: Liver samples were fixed in 10% formaldehyde and were embedded in paraffin for microscopic examination. Sections obtained from paraffin blocks (5 μm) were stained with hematoxylin–eosin stain.

sec.title: Statistics
sec.p: The experimental data were analyzed using one-way analysis of variance and Fischer’s least significant difference tests to determine whether any treatment significantly differed from the controls or each others. Results presented as mean ± SD values and the level of 0.05 was regarded as statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The hepatic antioxidant enzyme activities of SOD, CAT and GSH-Px and GSH content significantly decreased (p < 0.05) in the TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.) administered group (Table 1). The animals treated with high dose of AST (25 mg/kg) alone showed significant increases in the levels of GSH and in the activities of antioxidant enzymes (SOD, CAT and GSH-Px). Furthermore, application of ASTA significantly (p < 0.05) increased the activities of reduced antioxidant enzyme by TCDD.

caption.p: Changes in the activities of SOD (U/mg protein), CAT (U/mg protein) and GSH-Px (U/mg protein) and the level of reduced GSH (µmol/g tissue) in the liver of rats treated with ASTA (25 and 12.5 mg/kg b.w.), TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.) and their combination.a

tr.td: ASTA (12.5 mg/kg b.w.) + TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.)
ASTA (25 mg/kg b.w.) + TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.)

fn.p: SOD: superoxide dismutase; CAT: catalase; GSH-Px: glutathione peroxidase; GSH: glutathione; ASTA: astaxanthin; b.w.: body weight; TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin.
aEach value represents mean ± SD of eight animals; means in the same column followed by the different superscript letters present significant differences at p < 0.05 level.

sec.p: Table 2 shows the results of the liver MN assay in rats. The tested dose of TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.) induced a statistically significant increase in the formation of the number of MNHEPs, although ASTA (at both doses) did not change the MNHEPs number when compared with control group. Moreover, ASTA (at higher dose) minimized the increased MNHEP rates by TCDD.

caption.p: Results of liver MN assay in rats treated with ASTA (25 and 12.5 mg/kg b.w.), TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.) and their combination.a

tr.td: ASTA (12.5 mg/kg b.w.) + TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.)
ASTA (25 mg/kg b.w.) + TCDD (8 µg/kg b.w.)

fn.p: MN: micronucleus; b.w.: body weight; MNHEPs: micronucleated hepatocytes; ASTA: astaxanthin; TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin.
aEach value represents mean ± SD of five animals; means in the same column followed by the different superscript letters present significant differences at p < 0.05 level.

sec.p: In controls, microscopic examination showed liver parenchyma consisting of hepatocytes. Sinusoids and central vein were also clearly visible (Figure 1). The livers in TCDD-treated group revealed severe pathological damages such as paranchymal degenerations, sinusoidal dilatation and lipid accumulation (Figure 2(a) and (b)). The lower dose of ASTA alone compared with the controls did not lead to a histopathologic finding in liver samples (data not shown). However, the presence of ASTA with TCDD did not fully prevent hepatic lesions. The livers of rats showed sinusoidal dilatations and lipid droplets (Figure 3). Whereas, ASTA at higher dose displayed a strong protective effect against TCDD and prevented liver injury (Figure 4).

caption.p: The liver of control rats showing sinusoids (arrows) and central vein (CV; hematoxylin–eosin; ×68).

The liver of TCDD-treated rats showing (a) sinusoidal dilatation (double arrow), parenchymal degenerations (arrows) and (b) lipid accumulations (L; hematoxylin–eosin; ×68). TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin.

The liver of rats after treatment with TCDD and ASTA together at lower dosage, showing sinusoidal dilatation (double arrow) and lipid accumulations (arrows; hematoxylin–eosin; ×68). ASTA: astaxanthin; TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin.

The liver of rats after treatments with TCDD and ASTA together at higher dosage is similar to the control group; sinusoid (arrows) and central vein (CV; hematoxylin–eosin; ×68) are seen. ASTA: astaxanthin; TCDD: 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study examined the effect of ASTA treatment on liver injury resulting from TCDD. Our results indicated that although ASTA at lower dose did not fully prevent hepatic lesions, it especially could play a beneficial role by preventing MNs and changes in antioxidant enzyme activities at higher dose. The exposures of mice and rats to TCDD have resulted in increasd production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and lipid peroxidation (LP) (Hassoun et al., 2001; Jin et al., 2008). The greater expression of oxidative stress in liver exposed to TCDD might be due to the inactivation of the antioxidant enzymes (Jin et al., 2008). It has been suggested that free radicals and ROS are quenched by endogenous ketocarotenoids, such as ASTA (Jayaraj and Punja, 2008). Overproduction of ROS and nitrogen species can tip the oxidant:antioxidant balance, resulting in the destruction of cell membranes, proteins and DNA (Park et al., 2010). Therefore, under conditions of increased oxidative stress, dietary antioxidants become critical in maintaining a desirable oxidant:antioxidant balance. Our results revealed that ASTA in hepatic tissue exhibited significant antioxidant activity (increasing antioxidant enzyme levels) in a dose-dependent manner. Increased expression of antioxidant enzyme levels observed herein was in agreement with previous rat models for liver (Kang et al., 2001). The present study explored the ability of ASTA at higher dosage as a protective agent that induces improvement in antioxidant capacity against TCDD. In general, ASTA supplementation resulted in particular protection of lipid/membrane structures in hepatocytes after TCDD treatments, since (a) the ratio of GPX in ASTA/TCDD hepatocytes was reestablished to control/ASTA levels; (b) significant differences were observed in the activities of SOD and CAT in the livers of ASTA- and TCDD-fed animals. At doses of 25 and 12.5 mg/kg, ASTA showed induction of SOD in TCDD models, with values of 12.8% and 3.1%, respectively. At the same doses, ASTA increased the CAT levels with 32.6% and 3.7%, respectively. This means that the higher dosage of ASTA had significantly higher antioxidant activity than that of the lower dose of ASTA in both the enzyme systems. This is not surprising since ASTA has been reported as an efficient scavenger and quencher of ROS in lipid bilayers (Naguib, 2000). In vitro studies have demonstrated that ASTA is several folds more active as a free radical antioxidant than β-carotene and α-tocopherol (Park et al., 2010). Therefore, ASTA provides enhancement of the immune response (Okai and Higashi-Okai, 1996) and protection against diseases such as cancer (Jyonouchi et al., 2000) and ulcer (Kim et al., 2005) through scavenging of oxygen radicals. Accordingly, electron transfer from isoflavonoids to the carotenoid radical cation, as formed during oxidative stress, is faster in ASTA than with the other carotenoids, which may relate to the more effective antioxidative properties of ASTA and be in agreement with the highest electron accepting index of ASTA (Han et al., 2010). ASTA has 13 conjugated double bonds, in contrast to other carotenoids, which gives it a significantly greater antioxidant capacity. ASTA also has hydroxyl groups in the 3 and 3′ positions, making the molecule highly polar and dramatically enhancing its membrane function to protect against degenerative conditions (Shibata et al., 2001). Because of its polar end groups, ASTA spans the cell membrane bilayers allowing it to sit near the lipid/water interface, where free radical attack first occurs and contributes to cell membrane mechanical strength (Palozza and Krinsky, 1992). ASTA stabilizes free radicals by adding them to its long double-bond chain rather than donating an atom or electron to the radical (Kurashige et al., 1990). Thus, it can resist chain reactions that occur when a fatty acid is oxidized. TCDD increased oxidative stress in hepatic tissues (Hassoun et al., 2001). Oxidative stress has been postulated to be one of the deleterious factors for liver, and it was reported that antioxidant levels were significantly reduced in hepatic diseases (Jain et al., 2002).

ROS produced by activated macrophages and a consequent rise of LP caused direct activation of hepatic cells, leading to liver lesions (Svegliati Baroni et al., 1998). Our results also showed that the pretreatments of ASTA increased GSH retain at higher dose in liver cells. The present findings suggested that the antioxidative protection from ASTA was due to GSH and/or the enhancement of enzymatic antioxidant defense against TCDD. GSH is one of the most abundant intracellular antioxidants in animal cells and detoxifies endogenous ROS and/or exogenous oxidative damage (Kidd, 1997). In female mice, exposure to TCDD results in a significant depletion of GSH by oxidative stress in liver (Slezak et al., 2000). The observed decreases in GSH-related enzyme activities indicate that TCDD may induce oxidative stress in rat liver at relevant lower doses of TCDD by altering GSH metabolic mechanisms at the cellular level. GPX enzyme metabolizes peroxides such as hydrogen peroxide and protects cell membranes from LP (Twaroski et al., 2001). The observations suggested that antioxidant therapy has an important role in preventing tissue injuries including hepatic damages (Coskun et al., 2011; Nakamura et al., 2010). Kang et al. (2001) reported that ASTA caused an increase in the level of hepatic GSH and activity of SOD in carbon tetrachloride-treated rat. Recent studies showed the mechanisms of action by which ASTA reduced liver injury and included the antioxidant protection against oxidative injury (Curek et al., 2010). ASTA has an antioxidative effect on cell viability due to the induction of antioxidant genes and suppression of apoptotic genes (Jang et al., 2009). It was highly possible that ASTA via increasing the activity of antioxidant enzymes and/or GSH level decreased the oxidative stress, which consequently enhanced the stability of biological membranes with its chemical structure and interaction (Riccioni, 2009). The ASTA restored the activities of SOD, CAT, GSH-Px and reductase and the content of thiol groups in the salivary gland presented a positive effect on the oxidative protection (Leite et al., 2010). Again, oxidative damages were significantly decreased in lipids and proteins of human neutrophils after ASTA treatment (Macedo et al., 2010). The higher activities of SOD and CAT in ASTA-treated lymphocytes were associated with significant lower indexes of oxidative injury (Bolin et al., 2010).

The pathological effects in hepatic tissue of TCDD might also lead to disruption in the functional integrity of hepatocytes (Czepiel et al., 2010). In the present study, the TCDD elicited severe instances of liver damage (hepatocyte degeneration, sinusoidal dilatation and lipid accumulation). ASTA (at higher dosage) has a pronounced effect on the relative potency of TCDD. Our findings not only supported that ASTA was a potent hepatoprotective agent but also explained the action of ASTA on MNs. It was reported that the gene and the chromosome data could be phenotypically anchored to complementary histopathology and could be used to further elucidate the mechanisms involved in the adaptive and toxic responses elicited by TCDD (e.g. lipid accumulation) (N'Jai et al., 2008). TCDD-induced oxidative stress caused single-strand breaks in DNA from liver and brain tissues of rats (Hassoun et al., 2001). In our investigation, MN test was performed for the first time and is revealed that TCDD exposure increased the rate of MNs in hepatocytes. MN assay is a reliable test to indicate chromosomal damage (Yilmaz et al., 2008), and MN production is one of the key pieces of evidence for the possible involvement of antioxidant activity in oxidative DNA damage (Tung-Kwang et al., 2010). ROS can alter vital cell components like polyunsaturated fatty acids, proteins and nucleic acids (Halliwell and Gutteridge, 1990). The increased production of ROS, LP and DNA and membrane damage are always associated with the exposure to TCDD (Shertzer et al., 1998). ASTA acted as a potent oxygen radical scavenger shown to be beneficial to carcinoma prognosis (Rao et al., 2007). Recently, ASTA has been reported to possess anticancer properties (Nagendraprabhu and Sudhandiran, 2009). Dietary ASTA decreased DNA damage in young healthy females. Furthermore, the concentration-dependent effect of ASTA on DNA damage implied that this compound might be able to protect DNA (Park et al., 2010).

Collectively, ASTA treatment offered beneficial effects against TCDD injury in hepatic tissue. The observed effect of ASTA (at higher dosage) on liver enzymes and on MNs was reflected by a major protection against histopathologic alterations. The data were essential to properly address the usage of ASTA as a nutritional therapy for the prevention of TCDD toxicity.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
